intro: Malvastrum clandestinum, commonly known as the Mexican mallow, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its large, showy pink or red flowers that bloom in late summer. Its leaves are palmately lobed and covered in fine hairs, giving them a fuzzy texture. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in disturbed areas such as roadsides and open fields.
